https://prez.dev/description.@value: Compilation of terms that describe the classification of alteration in a rock, with a focus on hydrothermal processes (i.e. mineralogical, chemical and textural changes resulting from the interaction of hot aqueous fluids with the rocks through which they circulate, under evolving physico-chemical conditions), and excluding weathering, mineralization and direct metamorphic or magmatic processes. Classification is based on the identification of the most important alteration mineral, the distinctive mineral assemblage, or the chemical changes that have occurred during alteration. Definitions are largely from Pirajno (2009), the Glossary of geology (5th edition revised; Neuendorf et.al., 2011), Thompson et al. (1996), and Wikipedia.

A type of advanced argillic alteration where alunite-group minerals (alunite, natroalunite and jarosite) are the dominant phase. Typically related to the presence of abundant sulfate ions and Al-rich protoliths.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: A type of argillic alteration defined by intensive acid attack and more or less complete leaching of the alkali cations with complete destruction of the feldspars and mafic silicate phases, resulting in an assemblage of dickite, kaolinite, pyrophillite, baryte, alunite and diaspore. In addition, sulfides, topaz, tourmaline and a range of amorphous clays may be present. Found in porphyry systems, in the inner zone of hydrothermal base and precious metal-bearing veins, and most typically in high-sulfur hydrothermal systems.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#hist.@value: Thompson, JFH, Thompson, AJB and Allen, RL 1996, Atlas of alteration: A field and petrographic guide to hydrothermal alteration minerals: St. John's, Nfld: Geological Association of Canada, Mineral Deposits Division, 119p.

In addition, sulfides, topaz, tourmaline and a range of amorphous clays may be present. Found in porphyry systems, in the inner zone of hydrothermal base and precious metal-bearing veins, and most typically in high-sulfur hydrothermal systems.
